text: Angelina Jolie wrote a piece in The
Times his op-ed section today revealing
that she underwent a preventative double
mastectomy because she had a gene that
gave her an 87 percent chance of
contracting breast cancer back in 2007
The Times profiled a woman who made the
same decision Debra Linder will join us
in just a moment but right now I'm
joined by Amy Harman the reporter who
wrote that Pulitzer Prize winning 2007
piece on pre vipers Amy thanks for being
here thanks for having me Angelina
Jolie's piece makes it sound not like an
easy decision for a woman to make if she
has these genes but like a relatively
straightforward one well I thought
Angelina speech was great you know sort
of started with her having already made
the decision and sort of took off from
there about what what the process is
like I thought it was really important
and great that she wrote about it you
know but I was fascinated by the idea of
you know what leads up to that decision
the starting point for my story was
really the availability of this genetic
test for these two genes brca1 and brca2
so the average chance of getting breast
cancer for the average woman is American
woman is 12% but if you're a carrier of
one of these genes your risk climbs you
know enormous lita baby 7% it can be 87
percent between 60 and 90 percent and so
then it's the question is sort of what
you know what do you do with that
knowledge and you know you're really at
that point it kind of depends on where
you are in your life dad for example was
single she was 33 years old when I was
talking to her and she she hadn't had
babies yet breastfeeding was really
important to her mother and her mother
wasn't so sure Deb should get the
surgery she was probably the most
questioning and are you really sure that
you want to do that and make sure you
want to do it now it not possible to
prolong this a little longer give
herself a chance to find that special
person to be married to have her family
to nurse her babies you know one thing
obviously is that's a big deal for many
women is you know their their identity
is bound up and how they look and their
shape and she was concerned about you
know would she be attractive and one of
my favorite quotes from the story was a
friend of hers who had had cosmetic had
implants for cosmetic reasons was just
like you know
get them off you'll get new ones and
they'll be awesome and cute and perky
and I think that actually helped her
make the decision well speaking of dr.
Deborah Linder she joins us now via
Skype
dr. Linder in your case what have been
the ramifications of the surgery in your
life absolutely thanks so much for
having me and you know I think that as
Amy said this is such a personal
decision and there's so much that weighs
in to when to make this decision and why
to make it and I think for me there was
no looking back this was absolutely the
right decision for me even though I was
not married even though I had not had
babies yet now when I look back at my
decision I realized that I don't ever
have to look at my babies and worried
that they won't have a mother because of
breast cancer because my risk is so much
lower than anybody walking down the
street right now because of having had
the mastectomy you know there are tricky
things though this isn't all a bed of
roses I mean I've had two babies since
the article came out and both of them
were born preterm and both of them I
elected to by donor breast milk from a
milk bank in order to feed them until
they got to their due date because early
babies unfortunately have a much
stronger benefit from breast milk and
they do better than when their unform
eula but I think that you know it's
important to realize that the mastectomy
is not an easy thing to go through and
there are definitely ramifications but
for me it was absolutely the right
decision how old are you now I'll be 40
in December because the other part of
this gene being a carrier for this gene
it raises your chance of ovarian cancer
but initially no Angelina Jolie also
talks about right so right she mentions
that so and for the average woman I
think the chances it's low it's like
less than 10% and for someone with this
gene it's 50% so Deb had always said
that you were planning to get your
ovaries removed by the time you were 40
and I don't know if you're planning that
but well you know that's one of the
things that we had my husband and I had
to really talk about was how quickly did
we want to have our babies so that I
could have my ovaries removed and be
safe from ovarian cancer you know it's
interesting we talk so much about the
breast cancer risk because it is a
higher risk but in reality breast cancer
is much more survivable
then ovarian cancer when someone is
diagnosed with ovarian cancer the risk
of dying from their ovarian cancer is so
much higher and so for me I plan to have
my ovaries removed in December right
before I turn 40
